newsitem.title: LAOS: Laos seeks to power economy with natural resources.
newsitem.headline: Laos seeks to power economy with natural resources.

text.p: Faced with few other options for economic growth, impoverished Laos plans to vigorously exploit its rich natural resources in 1997, officials said on Thursday.

"We are putting hydropower as a high priority," said Leuan Somboukhanh, vice-chairman of the State Planning Committee. "It is the main sector that can generate...income for our government and for our people," he told Reuters in an interview.

He predicted that Laos' healthy economic growth -- 7.1 percent in fiscal year 1996 -- would continue to be driven mainly by the hydroelectric sector, with as many as 18 dams on the drawing board for the small, land-locked communist nation.
Although rich in natural resources, Laos' per capita gross domestic product (GDP) stands at just $350 per year.
The country's 4.5 million people remain heavily dependent on foreign aid, which averages from $200 million to $300 million per year, according to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).
While hydropower and forest products are the country's leading exports, the UNDP says farming remains the principal livelihood for most Laotians.

About 80 percent of Laotians are farmers who grow just enough to feed their own families, and floods last year are expected to create a rice deficit of 154,000 tonnes, according to the World Food Programme.
On a brighter note for the Laotian economy, however, inflation dropped in fiscal year 1996 to about 12 percent, down from 25.7 percent in 1995, according to government and UNDP data.
But the kip, Laos' currency, has weakened.
It is now trading at about 980 to the U.S. dollar, compared to 920 last year. Economic analysts blame inflation and the country's three-currency market regime for its fall.
The Thai baht, U.S. dollar and kip are used interchangeably in Laos.

The ruling Lao People's Revolutionary Party has been slowly implementing economic reforms since aid from Moscow began to dry up in the 1980s. Among other measures, Laos enacted a revamped investment law in 1993 which an international economist said is among the most progressive in the region.
Privatisation of state-owned companies has moved ahead and a $44 million construction project is underway at Vientiane's international airport.
"Economic reform is very gradual. The government is worried about it, but it is a necessity borne out of the collapse of the Soviet system," said one diplomat.
The UNDP expects construction and tourism to maintain rapid growth, but hydropower remains the priority.
"Hydropower is all there really is," the diplomat said. "Laos only has natural resources -- water, gems and timber -- and hydropower is the least environmentally destructive."

Monemany Nhoybouakong, environment director of the government's Science, Technology and Environment Organisation (STENO), agreed. "We have to be self-sufficent. We should base our (economic development) on our natural resources, and on our hydropower...in a sustainable manner," she said.
But analysts said the boost in hydropower, the country's main source of foreign exchange earnings, will not solve one problem: the country's heavy reliance on the Thai economy.
Laos is counting on the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand (EGAT) to buy much of its power, which makes some officials uncomfortable.
